Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Two-Stage Turnbull-Cutait Pull-Through vs. Standard Coloanal Anastomosis

Background: The two-stage Turnbull-Cutait pull-through hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis may offer benefits in reducing postoperative morbidity compared to the standard hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis with diverting ileostomy in patients undergoing surgery for low rectal cancer.

Methods: This multicenter randomised clinical trial was conducted at Bellvitge University Hospital, Valle dâ€™Hebron University Hospital in Spain, and Instituto Nazionale Tumori Fondazione G. Pascale in Italy. Patients eligible for ultralow anterior rectal resection were randomised to either the two-stage Turnbull-Cutait pull-through or standard hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis with diverting ileostomy. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment. Neither patients nor surgeons were blinded. The primary outcome was 30-day postoperative morbidity, including complications from ileostomy closure in the standard group. Data were collected from June 2012 to October 2018.

Results: Ninety-two patients were randomised, with 46 in each group. The 30-day postoperative complication rate was 34.8% in the two-stage group and 45.7% in the standard group (difference = -10.9, 95% CI, -29.5 to 8.9; P = .40). Seven patients in the standard group did not undergo ileostomy reversal, and one patient in the two-stage group did not undergo delayed anastomosis. Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis. Adverse events were not specified.

Interpretation: The two-stage pull-through hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis is safe and does not increase postoperative morbidity compared to the standard approach with diverting ileostomy. Trial Registration: NCT01766661. Funding: Not specified.
